key_title: Key to the species of Melaleuca

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Myrtaceae

source.author: Spencer, R.D.
source.title: Melaleuca
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Spencer, R.D. (1996). Melaleuca. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves decussate
Leaves alternate or verticillate
Leaves with 1 or 3 veins or veins obscure
Leaves with 5–7 veins; flowers pale yellow to cream
Leaves shortly but distinctly petiolate; flowers whitish or red
Leaves more or less sessile; flowers pink or purplish
Inflorescence a lax spike; stamen bundles somewhat plumose with 30–70 short filaments arising along the length the claw
Inflorescence a dense spike, head or flowers in small clusters; stamen not as above, less than 30 per bundle
Leaves 1–4 cm long, 4–10 mm wide; flowers in a dense spike; stamens red
Leaves less than 1 cm long and 4 mm wide; flowers in short heads or loose clusters; stamens whitish
Bark not papery; leaves narrowly elliptic, 5–10 mm long, 2–4 mm wide; flowers in lateral heads on old wood
Bark papery; leaves linear-lanceolate, 3–7 mm long, 1–2 mm wide; flowers in terminal clusters on new wood
Flower clusters 1–1.5 cm wide; fruits finally immersed in the swollen stem
Flower clusters 2.2–3.3 cm wide; fruits not immersed in stem
Leaves linear to narrowly oblanceolate, 4–15 mm long, mostly suberect, incurved towards tip
Leaves ovate to obovate, 2–6 mm long, spreading, recurved at apex
Leaves ovate to broadly ovate, somewhat pungent, with numerous faint longitudinal veins
Leaves not as above
Staminal claw 5 mm or more long; filaments 13–18 per bundle; leaves 1.5–2.5 cm long, their tips recurved and hook-like
Staminal claw less than 5 mm long; filaments 4–14 per bundle; leaf tips not recurved, or leaves mostly more than 2 cm long
Fruits not in globular heads (either solitary, in few-flowered clusters, or in cylindric spikes)
Fruits in globular heads
Leaves obovate to elliptic, more than 3 mm wide
Leaves linear or lanceolate, less than 3 mm wide
Flowers 1 per bract, pink to purple; leaves less than 14 mm long, lanceolate with 3–5 veins, upturned towards tip
Flowers 3 per bract, white or yellow; leaves more than 14 mm long, terete with a recurved tip
Flowers terminal on new growth, the tips growing out into leafy shoots
Flowers lateral on old wood, the tips not growing out into leafy shoots
Leaves elliptic to narrowly ovate, (1–)3–7 mm wide
Leaves linear to narrowly elliptic, 1–3 mm wide
Leaves alternate; stamens more than 10 mm long, green; capsules more than 6 mm wide
Leaves in whorls of 3 or some alternate; stamens less than 10 mm long, usually yellowish or white; capsules less than 6 mm wide
Leaves usually in whorls of 3, more or less linear; flowers 1 per bract
Leaves not in whorls, linear to narrowly elliptic, flowers 3 per bract
Stems and leaves pilose
Stems shortly appressed-pubescent or glabrous; leaves more or less glabrous
[link through]
Bark mostly papery. Flower cluster more than 1 cm wide, stamens usually 7–12 per bundle; oil glands not or hardly protruding when fresh, indistinct when dry
Bark rough, scaly; flower cluster less than 1 cm wide, stamens 4–7 per bundle; leaves rough with protruding oil glands when fresh, black-dotted when dry
Staminal claw less than 3 mm long; leaves linear, oil glands usually distinct(at least on young leaves); widespread in south-eastern Victoria, commonly in swamps and near streams
staminal claw usually at least 3 mm long; leaves linear to very narrowly ovate or very narrowly obovate, oil grands obscure; cultivated plants
